heisigStory: The part of the apron where one finds the buckle (represented pictorially by the first 5 strokes) is on the sash.
koohiiStory1: First, note that the top half of the kanji consists of one and mountain. Of course, the "number 1" mountain in Japan is Mt. Fuji. The bottom half, under Mt. Fuji, consists of crown and towel. Now for the story. Archaeologists digging under Mt. Fuji (Japan´s #1 mountain) in an ancient royal tomb (they know it´s royal because of the crown) discover what looks like a towel, but after they clean it up, they see it is actually a splendid royal sash for the king´s kimono.
koohiiStory2: Beautiful "Miss Housewife Japan" is on posters everywhere, cooking right before Mt. Fuji (the number one mountain) while wearing nothing but her crown, and an apron tied with a sash. (hodgepodge of mspertus, zwarte_kat, et al, with a jot of hadaka apron to focus the image.).
myStory: dây lưng. bán 30 cái ở chợ
readingExamples: 帯びる (お.びる), 帯 (おび)
words:
一帯(いったい): a region, a zone, the whole place
帯びる(おびる): to wear, to carry, to be entrusted, to have, to take on, to have a trace of, to be tinged with
携帯(けいたい): carrying something
世帯(せたい): household
連帯(れんたい): solidarity
帯(おび): kimono sash
温帯(おんたい): temperate zone
寒帯(かんたい): frigid zone
地帯(ちたい): area, zone
熱帯(ねったい): tropics
包帯(ほうたい): bandage, dressing
